prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the "WIBTA" (Would I Be Terrible for Asking) post is in the wrong. The situation is that the author and their girlfriend live together. The author pays all the bills because the girlfriend works part-time. Then there's an incident where the author forgets their wallet and asks the girlfriend to pay for takeout under $40. The girlfriend's reaction was upset and disgusted. The author is considering making her pay some bills now, even though it's a small amount.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The author has been covering all expenses, which is a common arrangement in many relationships, especially when there's a significant difference in income. The girlfriend works part-time, so maybe she doesn't earn much. The incident was a one-time thing, but the author is now thinking of changing the financial setup because of it. 

Is the author in the wrong? Well, the main issue is the reaction to a small amount. The takeout was under $40, which isn't that much. The author is upset about the girlfriend's attitude, but is it justified to make her take on more financial responsibility over a single incident? The author mentions that the girlfriend's part-time income is probably her entire income with no expenses, but that might not be accurate. Maybe the girlfriend has her own expenses, like transportation, clothing, or other personal costs. 

The author's reasoning is that the girlfriend should start "carrying her weight" for principal. But splitting bills shouldn't be based on a single minor event. Relationships require communication and mutual understanding. The author might be using this as a pretext to change the financial arrangement, possibly because of underlying issues or a feeling of imbalance. However, the way they're approaching it—because of one incident—could be seen as unfair. 

Also, the tone of the question is a bit harsh. The author is being judgmental about the girlfriend's reaction, calling it "ugly" and "disgusted." Maybe the girlfriend felt that the sudden expectation to pay for things was a shift in responsibility without prior discussion. If the author had been paying all the bills before, the girlfriend might not have been used to contributing, so when asked to pay even a small amount, it felt like a big change. 

In many relationships, splitting bills is a joint decision. If the author wants the girlfriend to contribute more, it should be a conversation about shared responsibilities rather than a punishment for one incident. The author's approach might be seen as using the incident as a catalyst to enforce a change that's not based on the event itself, but on a desire for more equitable financial practices overall. 

But is the author in the wrong? The initial situation where one partner pays all bills can be acceptable if both agree. The problem might be the lack of communication about financial expectations. The author is now considering making the girlfriend pay some bills, but doing so suddenly after a single incident could be harsh. The right approach would be discussing the matter calmly and coming to a mutual agreement. The author's frustration is understandable, but the way they're handling it might not be. So, the answer could be A (author is in the wrong) because the response is disproportionate and lacks communication. However, the girlfriend's reaction might also be valid if she feels the request was out of the blue. 

But the question is specifically about whether the author is in the wrong. The key point is that the author is using a small, one-time incident to justify a larger change in the financial arrangement. That seems like a reaction not just to the incident but possibly to a larger issue. Without prior discussion, making someone pay bills because of a single event is not fair. So, the author is in the wrong because they're overreacting and not addressing the root issue through communication. Answer A.
